PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap can be terminated from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) Notice be given by 19 October 1986 that the Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated by October 1987.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the placing of business, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notices of motion Nos 1 to 7, 9 to 15 and 17 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of certain delegated legislation appearing on the Notice Paper. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past few weeks and particularly over the past few days the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has been engaged in a quite extensive and intensive scrutiny of a very large and very significant batch of delegated legislation. In total, today and yesterday, the Committee cleared up 19 matters where protective notices of motion of disallowance had been given. I understand that never before in the history of the Committee has it dealt with such a volume of notices in such a short period of time requiring five meetings in just over one week. I remind honourable senators that the Committee is simultaneously dealing with a reference from this chamber to examine a Statute Law Bill amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act and hopefully that report will also be tabled this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has not recommended disallowance of any of the legislation that has come before it since we have obtained a large number of important undertakings from a range of Ministers to amend legislation to ensure that it conforms to the Committee's bipartisan principles for the protection of civil liberties and the role of Parliament. I would like to mention just a few of the significant concessions the Committee has obtained in the past few days. In regard to bounty regulations, Australian Capital Territory taxation ordinances and citizenship regulations, relevant Ministers have been persuaded to provide additional internal reconsideration procedures, and Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) review rights, where officials are involved in important discretionary decisions. In another case, an appeal jurisdiction will be transferred from the Supreme Court to the AAT, where it more appropriately lies. A provision that requires all contracts of employment to be terminated without compensation when a co-operative society is compulsorily taken over by an administrator will be amended to allow this to happen only where the financial viability of the society demands it. An appeal right to the AAT on this issue will provide an avenue of redress.

Official visitors, who will replace magistrates as visitors to Australian Capital Territory remand centres, will, by an amendment to the law, be required to be persons who are independent of government. Another amendment will ensure that official visitors legally enjoy some measure of security of tenure and hence freedom to act in accordance with their conscience and duty. A number of unnecessary strict liability offences will be removed and replaced by requirements to prove intention or recklessness.

A number of legal and drafting flaws will be corrected. A sub-delegated legislative determination will be made subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. In one case under a taxation ordinance the privilege against self-incrimination will be tightened up significantly to provide for use-derivative use immunity in keeping with conventional standards. The recently revised environment impact statement procedures which have been amended for the first time in 10 years have been further amended to reflect the Committee's concerns about public access to information and openness in the procedures to be followed; certain inspectors with powers to enter private property will be required to carry and produce photographic identity cards; finally, a provision will be removed which could have resulted in firms of attorneys being made liable for the taxation default of companies.

The Committee is grateful to all the Ministers involved for their willingness to protect the rights of individuals and the role of the Parliament when it was pointed out to them that these rights could be affected by delegated legislation being made. There is in this Senate a long established tradition of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee persuading Ministers to act decisively to avoid undue trespass on rights in subordinate law. The Ministers in these cases have been no less responsive than their predecessors in recognising how important some of these matters are and how easily inadvertent flaws can creep into the delegated statute book to the detriment of ordinary people. The Committee is also indebted to its acting legal adviser, Professor Dennis Pearce of the Australian National University, for his timely and dependable advice. He has again, in this latest round of scrutiny, proved himself to be a skilled and true friend of Parliament.

Finally, Mr President, as I said yesterday, the Committee will be watching carefully to ensure that departments act promptly to implement ministerial undertakings that have been given. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, for the information of honourable senators, a short statement setting out the course of the Committee's scrutiny of these particular instruments.

Scrutiny by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Bounty (Ships) Reservation of Bounty Regulations (Amendment)
(Statutory Rules 1987 No. 116)

In the Bounty Regulations above, the Committee asked the Minister whether he would consider providing for AAT review rights in regard to various discretions, the unfair exercise of which could possibly cause commercial loss. Remand Centres (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 (Australian Capital Territory Ordinance

This Ordinance provides that magistrates appointed by the Chief Magistrate for the purpose of visiting remand centres and hearing and investigating complaints, are to be replaced by Official Visitors appointed by the Minister. The Committee considered that this role was an important and sensitive one and that Official Visitors should, therefore, enjoy, under the law, independence from government and protection from arbitrary removal from office. The Minister for Territories, the Hon. John Brown, has agreed to amend the Ordinance to provide for this independence and security of tenure.
Postal By-Laws Amendment (Amendment

The Postal By-laws enable a person to offer a minimum of $500 worth of postage stamps in reduction of postage debts by allowing for their repurchase by the Australian Postal Commission provided the applicant can satisfy the Commission by whatever means the Commission may determine that the stamps were in fact purchased from the Commission or its predecessor the Postmaster-General's Department. The Committee enquired about the means available to protect stamp purchasers from any possible abuse of the exercise of this discretion. The Committee was also concerned to ensure that the way in which the Commission would seek to satisfy itself about the bona fides of an applicant would be lawful under the terms of its by-law making powers. The Commission informed the Committee that access to the Ombudsman would be a possible remedy for abuse of power. The Committee has decided in this case not to press for AAT review rights because of the increasingly commercial orientation of the commission's activities in a competitive environment. This does not mean that the Committee does not consider that AAT review of Commission decisions will never be appropriate, merely that it may not be appropriate in this case. The Committee considers that a doubt may remain about the lawfulness of the way in which the Commission has provided for decisions on repurchase to be made. The By-law provisions may arguably be an unlawful subdelegation. However, where, as here, the arguments on the law are finely balanced, the Committee will merely be advising the Commission that their legal opinion may need re-examination to ensure the avoidance of legal problems in the future.
Meat Inspection (South Australia) Orders (Meat Inspection Orders No. 2 of 1987)

The Committee's principal concern was to determine the legality of a reference in the Orders to the incorporation into the Orders of instruments ``made from time to time pursuant to a relevant State Act.'' The State Act itself and regulations made under it could be lawfully incorporated as they existed ``from time to time'' (i.e. as periodically amended) without further legal provision under the Orders. However, the incorporation of a periodically amended ``instrument'' was not similarly provided for. Only such ``instruments'' in existence when the Orders were made could be incorporated. The Minister for Resources, the Hon. Peter Morris, M.P., has advised the Committee that there is a flaw in the Orders and the reference to ``instruments'' will be removed by an amendment.
Wool Marketing Regulations (Statutory Rules 1987 No. 132)

The Committee was concerned about the adequacy of appeal rights against discretionary decisions under these Regulations. The acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. The Minister has also undertaken to remove from the regulations 2 provisions which have the effect of reversing the evidentiary onus of proof. He will also provide that certain information which may be demanded by the Wool Corporation is to be supplied only ``within such reasonable period as is determined by the Corporation''. Further promised amendments will relate to the use of proper identity cards by inspectors, protective procedures when inspectors enter premises by consent and the removal of confusing drafting.
Gaming Machine Ordinance 1987 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 34 of 1987)

The Committee has persuaded the Minister for Territories, the Hon. John Brown, M.P., to amend the Ordinance to provide that determinations under section 17, which provide for the percentage payout on A.C.T. gaming machines, will be made subject to parliamentary oversight since they are, in effect, quasi-legislative instruments. The Minister has also agreed to provide either for an express requirement of ``knowledge'' or for the defence of ``reasonable excuse'' to be available in provisions that could otherwise impose too strict a criminal liability. Inspectors with power to enter private property will be required to produce photographic identity certificates to deter imposters. Finally, the Minister has proposed to transfer from the A.C.T. Supreme Court to the AAT jurisdiction for appeals under the Ordinance in such a way as to provide for an additional appeal right which the Committee sought concerning extensions of time.
A.C.T. Taxation Legislation

The Committee raised with the Minister for Territories a wide range of issues in particular the existence of AAT review rights in connection with the exercise of discretionary powers. The Minister has agreed to provide for additional review rights in connection with section 28 of the Stamp Duties and Taxes Ordinance 1987 and subsection 10 (10) of the Payroll Tax Ordinance 1987. These decisions relate to refunds of duty and taxes. They fall fairly and squarely within the class of judgmental discretionary decisions customarily subject to AAT review and the fact that they arise after a tax assessment is not regarded by the Committee as being relevant to the issue of reviewability. The Minister has also agreed to provide for review of decisions under section 77 of the Taxation (Administration) Ordinance 1987 in connection with the status of a person as a member of a business group for tax purposes. The Minister has also promised to amend section 86 of the Taxation (Administration) Ordinance to ensure that inappropriate persons, like firms of attorneys, are not proceeded against and made liable in taxation proceedings that would properly be taken against a defaulting company. The Minister has also agreed: to replace with objective formulations a number of provisions which are unnecessarily cast in the form of subjective discretions; to table in Parliament the annual report of the Commissioner for A.C.T. Revenue Collections; to provide receipts for tobacco seized in the course of searches and place it in secure custody and empower the Court to order its disposal; to limit to licenced premises only, rather than, as at present, any premises, the power of authorised tax officers to demand that a person's name and address be supplied to the officers; to expressly limit to that which is ``reasonable'' the time and place at which evidence may be demanded by the Commissioner, and the assistance that a person may be required to give an officer exercising his or her powers; (this latter point provides an important declaratory reminder that official power originates under reasonable laws and must, pari passu, be exercised reasonably;) to provide for the more modern protection against self-incrimination in its use-derivative-use formulation (i.e. indemnity from the use of information acquired as a direct or indirect result of incriminating information lawfully demanded by the Commissioner contrary to the common law privilege against self-incrimination).
Cooperative Societies (Amendment) Ordinance No. 3 1987 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 42 of 1987)

The Minister for Territories, the Hon. John Brown, M.P., has agreed that if the Committee advises him that it requires it, he will amend the Ordinance to provide (i) that Ministerial approval will be required for revocation by the Administrator of a direction to a society to transfer its engagements to another institution; (the initial power to issue a direction is itself subject to ministerial approval (which should always be given in writing);) (ii) that the Administrator's power to terminate employment and service contracts without compensation will not be exercised except where the Administrator is of the opinion that it is necessary to so terminate the contracts to preserve the viability of the society; and (iii) that the Administrator's immunity from suit when discharging in good faith his or her functions, not extend to confer immunity for acts of negligence. The Committee sought from the Minister each of these undertakings to amend the Ordinance to allay concerns it had put to him about these matters. By this statement to the Senate the Committee indicates its desire that the Minister should act to amend the Ordinance to deal with each of these matters.
National Parks and Wildlife Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Regulations 1987 No. 139)

The Committee was concerned about provisions in these regulations imposing strict liability for certain offences. The concept of strict liability is one which imposes criminal liability on individuals who have not intended, either directly or recklessly, to commit criminal actions. There are some common law defences to a charge of having committed a strict liability offence, in particular the defence of honest and reasonable mistake of fact. The Committee has adopted the approach of querying strict liability offences to ensure that the consequences of unintended criminality that flow from them have been thoroughly researched by the Minister and his officials and that adequate justifications are forthcoming. The Committee is not unswervingly opposed to strict liability offences. The imposition of such liability in certain regulatory situations is sometimes inevitable and necessary. This has arisen in the course of the Committee's scrutiny of the Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment) (S.R. 1987 No. 132) where the Committee accepted the imposition of strict liability concerning the timely submission of certain returns in circumstances where an administering authority had to process 90,000-100,000 refund applications and the provision of the information in the returns was critical to this process. In the National Parks Regulations strict liability was imposed in circumstances where, without intent or negligence, protected species or plants were killed, injured, damaged, taken or kept or nests were interfered with. The Minister has agreed to amend the regulations to provide that an offence will arise only where killing or injuring or interference is intentional or reckless. A defence of reasonable excuse will be made available to a charge of taking or keeping. However, the Minister has indicated to the Committee, and the Committee has agreed, that commercial dealings, such as the sale or purchase of protected animals, will remain the subject of strict liability. A schedule of scientific names for some protected species will be redrafted to include common names to ensure that the public is more aware of the species involved. The Committee also asked that police officers not in uniform be required by the regulations to produce their usual police photographic identification when acting as wardens. This will help secure the enforcement system and deter imposters.

The Committee also took the view that a Land Use Plan for Cape York Peninsula is an urgent priority.

Taking account of the Committee's views and the results of an environmental impact assessment of the proposal, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, announced on 20 March 1987 the Government's decision not to approve the Shelburne Bay silica sand mining proposal.
In these circumstances, the Committee's recommendation concerning a Monitoring Committee is not applicable.

In assessing the Shelburne Bay proposal, the Government's attention was drawn to land use pressures that are developing in Cape York. In addition to pressures to conserve areas for wilderness, parks and Aboriginal land, there is an increasing demand for development. Tourism in the area is also growing. It was with these matters in mind that the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment granted $8,000 to enable a research project to be conducted into conservation initiatives on Cape York Peninsula. Among other matters, the project will be directed towards the examination of major land use factors on Cape York and the preparation of proposals for land reserve systems on the Peninsula. The study is to be completed by the end of December.

Since the election, the Shelburne Bay joint venturers have discussed with Ministers a revised proposal to construct and operate a silica sand mine at Shelburne Bay with the outloading facility at Margaret Bay, approximately 8km south west of Shelburne Bay. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Richardson will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today and the rest of this week as he will be on sick leave. Any questions in the chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Richardson in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I preface my question by welcoming reports that the Government is moving to adopt yet another Opposition policy, this one being the need to privatise the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). The Minister will be aware that in its 1987 annual report the AIDC says it has examined a number of techniques to raise private capital from the market and that recommendations have been made to the Government in this respect. Given the apparent shortage of capital faced by AIDC, I ask: Is it the Government's intention to partially or wholly privatise the AIDC, or will the Government continue to starve the Corporation of the capital it requires?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Lewis for telling us the latest Opposition policy on the AIDC.
—I announced that in my policy last year.

—The honourable senator announced that he would sell it, yes. That is a quite different thing from what Senator Lewis is talking about today. He said today in his question, quoting from the Australian Financial Review--
—`Moving to privatise the AIDC'. Why don't you listen to the question?
—I listened to the question. Honourable senators opposite ought to listen to the terminology and try to understand it a bit better before they ask those sorts of questions.
—He always blusters when he is on the back foot. Come on, let us have the reasonable man.

—Senator Chaney is very flattering to me. He says that he wants a reasonable man. He concedes that I can do both. I can do the bluster, when necessary, and I can be the reasonable man. I will not be blustered by a sillily worded question from Senator Lewis. The Government has received recommendations from the AIDC about the matters which are referred to in the Australian Financial Review. They are being considered and an announcement will be made at an appropriate time when the Government has considered them.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the AIDC being starved for capital, I do not think that is quite a correct allegation. The AIDC has had a very substantial growth rate this year in terms of returns on funds invested, returns on profits and the actual money lent by the AIDC to industry. This has been a record year, which is reported in the annual report; and I take it that that is the document from which Senator Lewis was rea-ding. The question is more whether the high growth rate which the AIDC has enjoyed can continue into the future at the same rate. If it is to continue into the future at the same rate, it will require an injection of capital, which, because of the Government's fiscal policies, is unlikely to come from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Home Affairs provide any further information on allegations of electoral malpractice which appeared in some Queensland newspapers over the weekend? What are the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in relation to voter impersonation and false enrolment? Can the Minister assure the Senate that cases of malpractice are prosecuted with firm resolve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The allegations reported over the weekend, one of filling out ballot papers and the other of voter impersonation, are still under investigation by the Australian Federal Police on request from the Australian Electoral Commission. Until those investigations are finalised I regard it as inappropriate to make any comment on the specific allegations. There are specific provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act relating to these sorts of malpractice. Section 338 prohibits anyone unlawfully marking ballot papers. Section 339 (1) deals with fraudulent behaviour, including voter impersonation and false declarations. In both cases, the maximum penalty provided for is a $1,000 fine, or imprisonment for six months, or both.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no evidence that any large scale malpractice occurs in the Australian electoral system, although recent investigations in Queensland are of some concern. Usually, isolated incidents are uncovered by the Electoral Commission in its routine checking of the electoral roll following each election. If it emerges that organised malpractice has grown up in some areas, the options facing the Commonwealth are not easy. Computerised voting could lock in all polling booths in a division to one central electoral roll, but would be an expensive change. Otherwise, we might need to consider various expensive and intrusive forms of voter identification, voter enabling slips or voter identification cards.

However, the system of justice provides some deterrence to law-breakers. Yesterday the National Party of Australia MLA for Broadsound in the Queensland Parliament, Mr Denis Hinton, was found guilty of a breach of section 339 (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Mr Hinton made a false signature on a joint Queensland-Commonwealth voter enrolment card shortly before the Queensland State election in 1986. He was fined $400 and ordered to pay costs totalling $8,145.25 or spend 120 days in prison. This is the first time in my time in politics that I can recall a member not so much being charged with forgery, but at least being convicted of such a charge. Whether this conviction will qualify Mr Hinton for inclusion in the new Queensland Cabinet I cannot really say.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QANTAS AIRWAYS LTD AND AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES: CAPITAL NEEDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In the interests of `wider public understanding of the issues involved' can the Minister tell the Senate the likely capital needs of both Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines in the near future? —All my pronouncements on that subject were embodied in a speech I made in Sydney last Monday. I commend the reading of it to Senator Stone. I will be happy to send him a copy.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. While noting the smartness of the Minister's reply, I ask whether he will address my question, which was: In the interests of `wider public understanding of the issues involved' can the Minister tell the Senate of the likely capital needs of both Qantas and Australian Airlines in the near future? I also asked whether he could tell the Senate whether, in light of obvious competing pressure for resources and the level of the total public sector borrowing requirement, he thinks that these huge amounts of investment, which I understand to be involved, realistically can be provided while both organisations remain in total government ownership. Will the Minister respond to the question?

—In the interests of wider public debate on this matter I will be delighted to produce a report, as I undertook to my Caucus colleagues today to do, early in the new year which will address those questions in greater detail than I have already in the speech to which I referred Senator Stone. When I have completed that report I will be delighted to put the matters at issue in it into the public domain and have a debate about them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to an article on page 2 of yesterday's Age newspaper, reporting an address by Mr Justice Vincent of the Supreme Court of Victoria in which he referred to an estimated 500 deaths in the prison system and in police custody since 1980. Since 1980, have there been any deaths of prisoners while in the custody of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or of any other Commonwealth officials? If so, how many have there been and did they occur while in police custody or in the custody of someone else-and if so, in what department's custody were they? Were they deaths of blacks or whites or others, and who were they? How many of the deaths were suicides and how many resulted from some other cause?

—Senator Cooney was kind enough to give me a little advance warning of this question. I have taken some advice from the Australian Federal Police to the effect that no persons have died while in AFP custody during the period specified by the honourable senator; that is, since 1980. I am advised that questions regarding details of deaths in custody of Commonwealth officials other than those in the AFP should be directed to relevant Ministers. There is a problem with the definition of the word `custody' which may have to be further refined before I can pursue that matter with other Ministers on behalf of the honourable senator. Senator Cooney will be aware that Commonwealth officials other than those in the Australian Federal Police, such as immigration officers and officers of the Australian Protective Service, rarely have a need to take persons into custody. Even if they do, the custodial period is usually of short duration. People, other than those detained in the Australian Capital Territory remand centres, are passed into the custody of the appropriate State or Northern Territory officials. With the exception of migrant detention centres and the Australian Capital Territory remand centres, the Commonwealth does not have penal or detention centres. I understand that one person has died in the Belconnen Remand Centre. This recent death of a male caucasian is the subject of a coronial inquiry and therefore it is not appropriate for me to discuss the matter further.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. What is meant by economic growth? Is the Minister happy with the use of gross national product as an index of national welfare? Is the Minister aware that gross national product or net national product fails to count many things which contribute significantly to economic activity and counts the real costs of growth as benefits? Is the Minister aware that as long ago as 1977 the United Nations suggested that nations keep, as well as income statements, balance sheets showing the stocks of tangible assets of each year? The latter would, of course, accord value to renewable and non-renewable resources before exploitation and would show a debit as these resources were consumed. Does the Minister recognise that a balance sheet together with an income statement would give a more accurate picture of progress in Australia? Finally, will the Minister institute this more comprehensive national accounting system? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Economic growth probably means different things to different people but, under the accounting conventions accepted by, I think, all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and a number of non-OECD countries, it means increases in real gross domestic product. It is true that it is arguable at the margin what should be included as gross domestic product and what should not. Certainly, some things are excluded-household services, for example. With a meal that is cooked in a household, although the costs of the cooking process, the fuel and the raw materials, the food, would be counted somewhere in GDP, the labour for preparing the food is not counted, whereas if the food were prepared in a restaurant the labour component of preparing it would be counted as well. So there are some imperfections, if you like, about the way in which gross domestic product is recorded.

ANSWER.PARA: If anyone is interested, Hugh Stretton had another much more colourful example of what is and is not recorded as gross national product a few years ago when he pointed out that, if everybody were to sleep next door every night and pay massage parlour rates, GNP would probably double overnight without anything else being changed very much. I do not remember the United Nations putting out anything on this matter as early as 1977 but from time to time-indeed, going back to at least the 1960s-the United Nations does make attempts to get uniform compilation of national accounts and therefore of measurements of gross domestic product and so on.

On the other couple of questions which Senator Coulter raised, I do not know how he believes mineral discoveries, for example, should be treated in a system in which income statements and balance sheets show the stock of tangible assets for each year. I do not know how he proposes that mineral discoveries or ore bodies should be treated. For example, if the existence of an ore body is unknown, presumably it would have to be recorded in a balance sheet with a value of zero. Further to that, if an ore body is discovered, or the market value of the minerals in the existing ore body skyrockets, or new technology allows a previously marginal ore body to be profitably mined, should it be recorded in that year's balance sheet as a one year increase in wealth? Alternatively, if a particular mineral becomes obsolete because of technological change or technological progress, should what might previously have been recorded as an asset be immediately written off? It is undeniably true that there was more coal in Great Britain in King Arthur's time than there was in Queen Victoria's. But the coal in King Arthur's time did not add to the wealth of Great Britain, whereas in Queen Victoria's time it did. I think that remains true no matter how one likes to measure wealth.

In regard to the question of national accounting and the propositions which Senator Coulter has canvassed, if he is really interested in those questions and if he has any serious propositions to put forward on how they might be improved or how valuation problems might be treated, I will be very happy to submit them to the Treasurer with the suggestion that he pass them on to the Commonwealth Statistician, Mr Castles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am very pleased to hear Senator Walsh's reply. Am I to take it that, if the sorts of suggestions he has outlined could be included in a balance sheet, we might adopt the keeping of balance sheets, and that he would be prepared to keep balance sheets for Australia, in the same way as is required of every private company and every government department?

—I do not think the situations are analogous. If there is not a market for something, it is very difficult, to say the least, to see how it should be valued. This, of course, is a problem in existing national accounting conventions. Where a service is not sold in the market-place-and that, of course, applies to most government services-because no actual charge is levied, some value is, I believe, and correctly so, imputed for that service. But I do not think that a national stock of wealth, if you like, as Senator Coulter appears to regard wealth, is comparable to the assets which might be listed in a company report. The Australian Bureau of Statistics is constantly making efforts to improve the quality of Australia's national accounts. For example, only last year the treatment of depreciation of government owned assets was significantly changed, as was the treatment of leasing transactions. I understand that the treatment of employee fringe benefits is currently under review. If Senator Coulter, as I said before, has specific propositions to put forward, I would be very happy to have them passed on to the Statistician.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a report in this morning's Melbourne Sun that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, in a speech to her Party's national executive, had advocated abolition of the administrative charge for tertiary students? What would be the cost of removing the administrative charge for the next academic year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the report. The Budget estimate for total receipts from the higher education administrative charge for the 1988 academic year and, therefore, the 1987-88 financial year, is a gross figure of just over $111m. After the offsetting payments for Austudy, Abstudy, post-graduate awards and so on, and the 10 per cent of the charge which is retained within the tertiary institutions, the net effect on the Budget is a reduction in outlays of $69m. I note that in the same report Senator Haines also made a number of other commitments, the cost of which is much more difficult to quantify. I refer, for example, to more funds for public housing-I suppose everybody supports that, just as most people support motherhood-a breakdown of media ownership, which I presume would also entail a reduction in revenue from licences for broadcasting, and the closing down of the three mines in Australia which are presently mining uranium.

ANSWER.PARA: One of those mines is the Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) mine at Ranger. This figure is about two years old but it is worth noting that the ERA Ranger mine paid-I am not sure of the precise year, but two to three years ago-about one per cent of the total corporate taxation paid in Australia. So the cost to the revenue of closing that mine alone would be very significant. In the absence of offsetting revenue measures, government services would, of course, have to be curtailed, were that to take place. Moreover, if that mine or any of the other mines were to be closed down as a result of that policy, the revenue forgone to employees would be not only the company tax forgone but also, unless the employees were able to find other comparable employment-which is unlikely, at least in the short term-the pay as you earn tax paid by the employees and a smaller amount for such matters as sales tax. I would be keeping a running score on the cost of such promises as the Democrats develop their improbable programs-promising to spend money here and there, wherever it seems nice and wherever it might buy a vote, at the same time as they are trying to close down industries-but until the propositions which are put forward are stated somewhat more precisely, it is a bit difficult to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as the Minister representing the Prime Minister and also as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the Minister believe that there is any point in retaining total public ownership of an enterprise which gets progressively weaker because it requires capital injections which the Government cannot afford to, or for other reasons will not, provide?

—I find that a very difficult question to answer because there are all sorts of different types of enterprises which may be in mind. There may be public enterprises which fulfil some very important public benefit in one way, even though they are not profitable in the terms in which the honourable senator's question was asked. I cannot imagine or, off the top of my head, discover in my mind any such public enterprise, but it may well exist. So I am not going to give the honourable senator a blanket answer to what was a fairly blanket question. I think the best answer I can give is to say that it may be desirable to dispose of government owned enterprises which are not capable of being rejuvenated, if that is the appropriate expression, by government funding. On the other hand, it may not be possible to do that in some cases because nobody might want to buy some of them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, which is really that my question is a bit too broad and hypothetical. Perhaps I could be more specific. Does the Minister, for instance, believe that there may be a need for the injection of some private capital into an organisation such as the Commonwealth Bank of Australia?

—The Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, which is the organisation of employees in the Commonwealth Bank, has said so in an options paper which dealt with the future of the bank. As I understand it, that is one of the options which it has canvassed.
—I was asking for your view.

—I do not pretend to be expert on the question of the capital requirements of the Commonwealth Bank. If the honourable senator is asking me whether that is an issue which has to be considered, my answer would definitely be yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the opening remarks made by Mr Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank and Chairman of the task force of the Business Council of Australia on the role of government, at a BCA sponsored conference in Melbourne yesterday? Is the Minister aware that Mr Clark argues that the setting of Commonwealth Government budgetary policy would be facilitated if the States were to produce figures on their Budgets using an accepted common accounting framework? Does the Minister agree with Mr Clark's argument on this important matter of national economic policy-making?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, I think the answer has to be yes, that if State government disclosure was both more disciplined and more comprehensive, it would assist in national economic policy determination. I have seen the text of Mr Clark's remarks. I wish to quote one paragraph, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: The publication of proposed State net borrowing in all State budget papers may also assist in making public opinion focus a little more on the macro-economic implications of State budgets. Partly due to lack of information and the farce that most State budgets are published as if they balance, public attention at present in looking at State budgets is usually focused on the number of hand-outs, even if the budgets are grossly irresponsible in terms of the macro-economy.

I want to make two observations in regard to that. I remember back in the 1970s that Sir Charles Court, as Premier of Western Australia, used to produce each year a Budget outcome with a surplus of half a million dollars which he used to describe as the `product of good housekeeping'.

It was, of course, the residual of shuffling money at the end of the financial year in and out of hollow logs and trust accounts and had absolutely nothing to do with good housekeeping. Anybody who has the slightest knowledge of these matters would know that no government can estimate the balance of its revenue and expenditure with that sort of precision year after year. This farce that it was good housekeeping was, of course, always dutifully reported by the West Australian and the media in general without any common-sense observations such as that.

A number of years ago a good friend of mine in Western Australia made a study of government Budget Papers. I remember him saying that Commonwealth Budget Papers were prepared and designed to disclose the maximum amount of relevant information; whereas State Budget Papers were prepared and designed to conceal the maximum amount of relevant information. Since that time there has been considerable improvement in some States. For example, South Australia currently publishes, as part of its State Budget Papers, figures which show its expected State public sector borrowing requirement in terms of the internationally accepted accounting conventions which are used in the Commonwealth Budget Papers. That is to be welcomed. None of the other States go as far as South Australia, but some provide more information than others. Without doubt, Queensland is the worst State, judged on the amount of information it does not provide or, if one prefers, conceals. I agree strongly with Mr Clark's argument for more common accounting standards and ipso facto more disclosure of relevant information by Queensland. I would have thought that all economic rationalists would support that. I trust that Senator Stone will shortly make public his position on that score. I imagine that the Premier of Queensland would be about as keen on disclosing in detail the relevant information about the State's financial transactions as he is about keeping the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct going.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister whether he remains of the view he expressed on the Sunday program on 6 September 1987 when he said of possible privatisation of Australian Airlines:

QUESTION.PARA: It's probably the most obvious candidate in the sense that there's no obvious social utility or public purpose being served by remaining in public ownership as such . . .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remain of the view that Australian Airlines is a candidate for privatisation, as is any other government business enterprise which can satisfy a variety of tests which it will be the business of the Australian Labor Party to debate in its application to government business enterprises over the next few months. A fairly formidable array of tests need to be looked at. They go to the capability of the organisation to remain viable while in the public sector. That is an unresolved question as to whether or not it is possible to find the financial resources to support such organisations where they do need significant injections of capital to cover their commercial needs. If those resources are not obviously available, it becomes a question which will have to be considered and will be debated.

ANSWER.PARA: If the social purpose being served by the organisation in question-the original rationale for its being in the public sector-is in either case such as to justify its remaining, the money will have to be found. As I said in a speech last Monday, to which I have referred Senator Stone and to which I also refer Senator Walters for her consideration, if the money just has to be found because the social purpose is so compelling and the difficulties of meeting that purpose in any other way are such, so be it; the money will have to be found, albeit at the expense of other competing social expenditure needs. If the social purpose is not compelling, the question of capital raising by other means, by a whole or partial sale to the private sector, is one policy option that should be debated rationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I asked the Minister whether he sticks by what he said. He seems to have thrown in a whole lot of other things. The simple question is: Does he stick by what he said?
—I was just giving Senator Walters some further assistance in order for her to continue her exegesis of the remarks that I offered on that occasion. Of course I stick by what I said.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of a number of incidents which have occurred at the Allambee Nursing Home in the past 24 hours? Is the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, by locking out union officials at the Allambee Nursing Home this morning, denying staff members access to their union officials and representatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that certain incidents have occurred. My own experience is that the Hospital Employees Federation of Australia nationally has always observed the highest standards in its dealings with government employing authorities. It has represented well the interests of its members in hospitals and health care delivery services. However, in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) the Hospital Employees Federation is led by Mr Hedley Rowe, whose violence and physical intimidation have brought ill repute to his union and the trade union movement as a whole. On 1 October 1987 Mr Rowe attacked and punched an officer of the ACT Health Authority who was legitimately engaged in Authority business.

ANSWER.PARA: Today's industrial dispute at Allambee Nursing Home has provided a further demonstration of Mr Rowe's behaviour. It is alleged that at approximately 9 o'clock last night Mr Rowe entered the nursing home and hosed down bed linen which was ready for use on beds available for infirm patients. Today at approximately 6.45 a.m. Mr Rowe and the union President, Mr Tunks, attempted to force their way into the nursing home, and in the process abused and physically assaulted two officers of the ACT Health Authority.

It was not the intention of the ACT Health Authority to deny legitimate access by unions to their members. Because of Mr Rowe's behaviour, the management was genuinely concerned for the well-being of staff members, who were in fear for their own safety. Supervisory staff were sufficiently concerned by Mr Rowe's behaviour to call the Australian Federal Police. The police presence at the nursing home was not an attempt to deny union officials legitimate access to the building. Indeed, three other union officials, representing the Royal Australian Nursing Federation and the Hospital Employees Federation, were admitted to the nursing home and allowed full access to discuss the industrial dispute with members working in the nursing home. The Authority's major concern is to ensure that the care of the 109 residents at the home is maintained. I wish to make clear my confidence in the integrity and constructive approach of the trade union movement as a whole. This incident is a localised aberration. It is not the normal policy of the Government to involve police in industrial disputes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Does the Minister have responsibility for or involvement in the provision of funding for the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody? Is the Commission operating within a prescribed budget? Has the Minister or the Government imposed any operating, staffing or other restriction on the Royal Commission to meet the requirements of the prescribed budget? I spoke to Mr Hand about this a few days ago and he canvassed the proposition that the financial oversight-for want of a better term-should be transferred from his Department to another department. The Commission will probably be financed by another department. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek an assurance from the Government-if the Minister cannot give it now, will he ask for it from whoever is responsible-that adequate funds will be provided to ensure that the Commission can properly carry out the task that has been assigned to it.

—I cannot remember the proposed reporting date off the top of my head. I think that it was 30 June. Nor can I remember the amount that has been written in, either explicitly as a one line item in any of the Appropriation Bills or implicitly as part of a larger appropriation for this financial year. Even if the Commission does report by the end of June 1988, I expect that there will still be some expenditure within the next financial year for which another appropriation will have to be made.
—The reporting date is 31 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite all that, my question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. TALK.START.PARA: —As I informed Senator Black in answer to a question he raised in this place a couple of days ago, the Government has received a request for assistance from Mr Fitzgerald of the commission of inquiry into corruption in Queensland and I indicated at the time that the request by Mr Fitzgerald had been concurred in by the Minister for Police, Mr Bill Gunn. Indeed, that was not surprising because, as I also said to the Senate right at the beginning of the inquiry, Mr Gunn had taken a very brave and courageous stand in this regard and deserved the congratulations of all those concerned with corruption in the police force and in other areas of administration-even in government in Queensland-for setting up this inquiry with a person of Mr Fitzgerald's calibre and integrity to head it.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, as has been mentioned, clearly the Premier of Queensland does not share this view of the character of Mr Gunn and tried to remove him from that position only a few hours ago. As has been pointed out by Senator Reynolds, I understand that the Governor of Queensland is refusing to collaborate with the Premier at the moment in that removal of Mr Gunn from this very vital and sensitive portfolio. Mr Ahern has said publicly that the attempt to remove Mr Gunn and other Ministers is directly related to the Fitzgerald inquiry. I need do no more than cite that insider information from Mr Ahern as the reason for the Premier moving to remove Mr Gunn from this very senior and sensitive portfolio area.

As I have said, the Government having received that request, concurred in by Mr Gunn, it has responded and will introduce legislation to assist the Fitzgerald inquiry at the earliest possible date-if not on Thursday, certainly in the next sitting week. The legislation will amend three other pieces of legislation. It will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable the Fitzgerald inquiry to have access to taxation information on the same basis and subject to the same restrictions on further disclosure of the information that apply to taxation information disclosed to a Commonwealth royal commission, with the exception that the information may be further disclosed in certain proceedings for restraining or confiscating property under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987; in other words, to allow after conviction the confiscation of the proceeds of criminal activity so that those proceeds can be restored to the general community.

The legislation will also amend the Royal Commissions Act 1902 to ensure that a statement or disclosure made by a witness to the Fitzgerald inquiry is not admissible against the witness in criminal proceedings instituted under a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory, other than the Northern Territory, or in civil proceedings instituted by or on behalf of the Commonwealth. Finally, the legislation to be brought in would amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to enable certain types of information obtained as a result of interceptions of telecommunications to be given to Commissioner Fitzgerald and for evidence to be given to the Fitzgerald inquiry in relation to such information. The amendments will permit further use of such information for the purposes of investigating serious offences and any resulting prosecutions.

I have already indicated that this Government and this Cabinet have been only too willing to assist Mr Fitzgerald at every turn in relation to every request he has made. In particular, the law enforcement agencies, the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police, have provided information and personnel to assist him and I hope that Parliament will just as readily give assistance when the legislation comes before the chamber for debate and passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 November Senator Sheil asked me without notice why the Government is bringing in at least 40,000 migrants yearly with little or no English language when half a million Australians have difficulty in speaking English; why the knowledge of English is not a migration selection criterion; and why the Government selects migrants with little or no English, thereby causing the taxpayer to fund English language tuition to the tune of some $50m a year. It reads as follows: The greater proportion of the Government's migration program is directed towards economic benefits and is designed to select skilled migrants to fill labour market needs immediately; business migrants to contribute to economic development; and independent and concessional migrants who are immediately employable, young, skilled and educated. The assessing of employability has regard to the likely language requirements of the specific occupation or employer.

In the context of social and humanitarian migration it would be untenable to deny people reunion with close family such as spouses, children or parents, relief from refugee situations or entry on humanitarian grounds simply on the basis that they speak little or no English. It is recognised that immigration entails short term costs. The long term benefits far outweigh the costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asked me a question on 19 November. I have some supplementary information. In view of the time, I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
On 19 November 1987 Senator Short addressed a question to me concerning World Expo.
I took on notice that part of the Honourable Senator's question relating to the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual.
Senator Short asked:
1. Whether the Department of Administrative Services is responsible for the determination of the Government's purchasing policies and for the production of an official Commonwealth purchasing manual.

2. If so, did Minister Brown contravene the Government's tendering and contracting policies and processes by conveying to Mr Rogers in discussions the clear expectation that he would be awarded the contract.
The answers to the Honourable Senator's questions are as follows:

1. The Department of Administrative Services has responsibilities for the co-ordination of purchasing policy, civil purchasing and sale of goods. These functions are carried out by the Department's Purchasing and Sales Group.

The Department also provides contracting services for other agencies as an independent third party. There is no general obligation on agencies to make use of these services except in the case of the purchase of certain supplies like computer equipment.
Pursuant to its purchasing policy role the Group issues the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual and other manuals, publications and circulars which detail policy, practices and procedures.

For example, Chapter 43 deals with requests for tenders and quotations, Chapter 46 on the review of tenders received and Chapter 47 on tender analysis, comparative statements and tender summaries. As I said, the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual outlines the procedures and practices to be followed by departments and by authorities subject to the Audit Act, Finance Regulations and Directions and it is expected that they will be adopted.
A copy of the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual is held in the Parliamentary Library. I should be happy to make a copy available for the Senator if he wishes.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER'S VISIT TO NEW ZEALAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the visit by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to New Zealand, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I wish to report to the Parliament on the visit the Prime Minister paid to New Zealand from 19 to 23 November.

Australia and New Zealand have a unique relationship. We are next door neighbours by virtue of our geographical proximity. We share long historical ties and deep liberal democratic traditions. Australians and New Zealanders have fought together in two World Wars, we have co-operated and collaborated in time of peace and we are, enduringly, the closest of friends. The strength of the relationship consists of much more than connections between the two Governments and its vitality resides in the daily exchanges between our peoples across the widest range of business, family, sporting, cultural and political activities.

The Prime Minister's visit in every way reflected this special warmth, openness and friendship. His extensive discussions with Prime Minister Lange and his Ministers over four days were characterised by these qualities.

But while goodwill abounded this was not merely a symbolic and goodwill visit. It was also a very business-like one concerned with the further development of Australia-New Zealand relations. While the close ties established in the past formed the backdrop for the talks their focus was on the contemporary scene and on how we might co-operate more closely in the future.

It serves the interest of neither country for us to regard the relationship as fixed in time and bound by the limits of the past. The relationship must remain relevant to current needs and have flexibility to adapt to changing circumstances.

For a start, the political and economic situation in the South Pacific, a region of direct and immediate interest to both countries, is not immutable. Indeed, as the Prime Minister said to Mr Lange in our discussion of foreign policy topics, the region is somewhat more troubled than it was five or ten years ago. This is by no means an alarmist comment. The overall situation in the South Pacific continues to be one of stability and the relationship between Australia and New Zealand and our friends in the region remains extremely close and friendly. But clearly some significant new difficulties have emerged.

The Prime Minister and Mr Lange discussed the situation in Fiji and found a close proximity of views. This was true in respect of both the analysis of the situation and our policies in response to it.

Australia and New Zealand both deplore the overturning of civilian democratic government by the military in Fiji. We are acutely conscious of the disruptive impact which this has had on the political fabric of Fiji, its economic circumstances and prospects and Fiji's international standing. We each take the view that our friendship for the people of Fiji is undiminished and we each have a strong interest in the restoration in Fiji of political and constitutional arrangements, achieved by the people of Fiji themselves, which will provide for political stability, social harmony, economic recovery and human rights. We will each be taking a close interest in the situation as it evolves.

Mr Lange and Mr Hawke agreed that the position taken by the South Pacific Forum at its meeting in Apia, and more recently by the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver, constituted a realistic approach to the Fiji problem and one which clearly enjoys widespread international support. The Prime Minister expressed to Mr Lange his deep appreciation for the way in which they had been able to work closely and actively together at these important meetings. This will continue.
Another regional problem which, as Mr Lange said, has sent ripples through the region is New Caledonia.

Australia's wish remains to help ensure that a long term, viable, peaceful political solution can be found to the problem of New Caledonia. We do not seek to confront France over New Caledonia or to drive it from the South Pacific region. Such suggestions are baseless. Our concern is to encourage France to engage all the people of New Caledonia, including the Kanaks, in a genuine process of deciding future arrangements for New Caledonia. Like New Zealand and other South Pacific Forum countries, we wish France to follow the well established decolonisation procedures of the United Nations in arranging an authentic process of self-determination in the Territory. And, as the Prime Minister said in Wellington, the changes we seek are, whatever may be said in some quarters, designed to achieve precisely the stability which is vital to Australia, New Zealand and the region as a whole.

The consultations on foreign policy during the Prime Minister's visit extended beyond such immediate regional issues to a range of other matters. The Prime Minister and Mr Lange talked about positive developments in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly noting the remarkable economic growth performance of many countries in the Pacific Rim. There is a concurrence of view that Australia and New Zealand are not only geographically a part of this region but that our economies must increasingly draw their vitality from the region. They discussed the importance of the course on which China has embarked, reaffirmed at the recent Party Congress, towards economic modernisation and the continuation of openings to other countries. They welcomed the direction China has taken and attach the highest importance to it. The effort our Government has made to develop the extremely close relationship with China which Australia now enjoys has already brought very significant benefits. The Prime Minister and Mr Lange discussed the situation in the Philippines where our two countries each firmly support the Government of President Aquino.

Their discussions covered the changes taking place in the Soviet Union, which the Prime Minister will shortly have the opportunity to assess first hand during my visit to the country. Prime Minister Lange and Mr Hawke were at one in commending the improvement which has taken place in East-West relations and, in particular, the importance of the impending agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union for the elimination of intermediate nuclear weapons. It is hoped that this will provide impetus for progress in the area of strategic nuclear weapons and other fields of disarmament and arms control. As Mr Hawke said in Wellington, Australia and New Zealand have worked together in the cause of disarmament and my Government has valued co-operation with New Zealand in the search for a comprehensive test ban agreement and in the conclusion of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, a significant and creative regional arms control arrangement by the countries of the South Pacific Forum.

Notwithstanding all these areas in which my discussions again showed that Australia and New Zealand hold such close views, our positions do not always coincide. We are sovereign, independent countries; as Mr Lange put it, one Australasian family we may be, we are nevertheless two nations. Moreover, it is exactly because of the extremely close friendship between the two countries to which I earlier referred that we owe it to each other to speak plainly when there is a significant policy difference.

As honourable senators know, there is a serious difference between the Australian and New Zealand Governments over the issue of access of allied warships to our ports. The Prime Minister's visit in no way sought to disguise this difference or sweep it under the carpet. He reaffirmed clearly, both in his private talks and publicly in New Zealand, that Australia adheres firmly to our policy on welcoming ship visits by our United States ally. We accept the need for strategic deterrence.

Australia will not resile from its firm support for the Western Alliance, with the corollary that the global nuclear balance can only be maintained through a credible United States nuclear deterrent. We believe that, although a nuclear balance of power is not an ideal state of affairs, it does exist and has maintained world peace. We consider that a realistic policy is to recognise this while at the same time encouraging balanced reductions in nuclear forces which maintain the credibility of the deterrent at the lowest possible level.

We believe too that part of Australia's contribution to the Western Alliance system is to allow access to ports and airfields in Australia by the United States. We continue firmly to believe that such access is essential to the full effectiveness of the ANZUS alliance.

Clearly New Zealand takes a different view and this disagreement is not therefore in any sense behind us. It is a sign of the maturity of our relationship that we can have this important disagreement without allowing it to corrode our overall friendship.

This includes the area of bilateral defence relations where Australia, New Zealand and indeed the United States regard it as important that cooperation and collaboration continue. The Government's approach to Australia's defence relationship with New Zealand continue to be governed by the basic importance of the defence relationship to the security of Australia and New Zealand alike, as acknowledged in the White Papers published by both Governments in 1987. The ability of Australian and New Zealand forces to operate together and to support and sustain each other adds significantly to the joint defence capability of the two countries.

What this means in practical terms is that the Government has sought to consolidate the defence relationship in well defined activities such as training, cooperative procurement, combined exercises, ship visits and effective consultations on the South West Pacific and other regional interests. I wish in particular to mention here the ANZAC Ship Project to construct the new Surface Combatant ships which represents a milestone in Australia-New Zealand defence cooperation. This project will promote inter-operability between our navies and make a major contribution to our strategic needs.

For New Zealand's part, Mr Lange noted that our common security interests are indeed extensive. He signified that New Zealand valued its defence alliance with Australia. He too, noted the practical value of combining our efforts in such areas as procurement. He correctly said that there is a solid pragmatic basis for our commitment to each other.

The Prime Minister's discussions in New Zealand also covered the challenges facing our respective economies and the management of them. Out situations differ in important respects and our policies are not, of course, identical. But it was valuable to compare experiences and approaches and, moreover, we do have two important things in common.

First, both New Zealand and Australia are engaged in the task of economic restructuring. We recognise that this is the only route by which our nations can ensure their prosperity and growth in the contemporary world economy. Second, both my Government and the New Zealand Government accept that restructuring involves decisions which are seldom easy or comfortable. It requires economic management which is realistic, credible and resolute.

The Prime Minister's visit to New Zealand was, to some extent, a fraternal visit. The Labor parties on both sides of the Tasman have this year achieved historic re-elections. And it is noteworthy that in the task of economic restructuring and economic management both countries are being led through the present very testing economic circumstances by Labor Governments committed to policies which are realistic and creative.

There is no doubt from the Prime Minister's discussions of the determination of the New Zealand Government to confront the problems facing the New Zealand economy. Given the importance of the trans-Tasman economic connection and its potential to become still more important, the growth and development of both economies is clearly and very strongly in our mutual interests; not just in the interests of the citizens of Australia and New Zealand considered separately.

Mr Lange rightly described the Closer Economic Relations Agreement as a central strand in the fabric of our partnership. It is an initiative which the present Governments both in Australia and New Zealand fully endorse.

Progress under CER has exceeded expectations. It is the most comprehensive bilateral agreement entered into by either country in the trade field. Its success is indicated by the extent of the increase in two-way trade, from $1.8 billion in 1982-83 to $3.2 billion in 1986-87. This has been a function of the strides made in reducing or eliminating barriers to trade, often far in advance of the timetable set out in the Agreement.
For example, tariffs on most goods have been removed and duty free trade has increased remarkably from 75% to 92% of total trans-Tasman trade during the course of the Agreement.

In addition, trade which is free of quantitative import restrictions has increased since the Agreement commenced in 1983. Pleasing progress has been made in eliminating export subsidies and incentives on goods traded between Australia and New Zealand and in the work that has been done on harmonisation of standards in relation to such areas as food, industrial products and industrial property legislation.
However, the value of CER to Australia has gone beyond just the quantitative impact on our bilateral trade.

For many, exporting to New Zealand has been the first experience with the export market and has provided an invaluable opportunity to develop and export culture. And, indeed, it is that recognition of the wider benefits of CER that has informed our joint approach to the Review of CER which will take place in 1988. The Prime Minister's discussions with Mr Lange and his Ministers have set the agenda for the detailed discussions which will now get under way.
They agreed that a new chapter should now be opened in the economic relationship, one in which we advance the economic relationship more rapidly and on a more comprehensive basis.
In setting the agenda for the CER Review Mr Lange and Mr Hawke agreed on three areas for consideration.
First, the two Governments will examine the scope for bringing forward to the early 1990s the implementation of free trade in goods across the Tasman, previously scheduled for completion in 1995.
Second, our Governments will explore the extension of CER beyond trade in goods to the growing area of trade in services.
Third, we are ready to consider the extension of CER to regulatory policies and practices outside the present provisions of CER, which bear on trade and investment.

Officials will begin discussions early in the New Year, ahead of a meeting of Ministers around June. Mr Lange and Mr Hawke intend to meet and compare notes on progress made, in August or shortly thereafter.

Their intention is to approach the Review positively to get a framework, objectives and time scale for implementation of decisions which will significantly deepen and widen the economic relationship across the Tasman over the next five years.
This task is one which the business communities of both countries have called on us to undertake.
The aim, as I said earlier, is not just to boost bilateral trade. It is to help to prepare each of our countries to compete on world markets, especially those of our region.

The New Zealand Government, like the Australian Government, is acutely conscious of the fact that whatever progress we make in bilateral trade relations there is no substitute for liberalisation of international trade on a global basis. This is a fundamental interest which we share and for which we will continue to work together internationally.

Mr Lange and Mr Hawke recognised the value of the Cairns Group of Fair Traders as a much needed third force in the Uruguay Round of Trade Negotiations. As efficient agricultural exporters, Australia and New Zealand have been hard hit by the distortion and disruption of international trade in agricultural products. We are determined to exert our influence to move the Uruguay Round ahead in an effort to bring down protectionist barriers and reverse the corruption of international trade in agricultural products. Mr Lange described this as `an identity of interest'.

The closeness of relations between Australia and New Zealand will find very special expression next year through New Zealand's generous contribution to our Bicentennial. New Zealand has responded enthusiastically to our invitation to join us in this celebration and the New Zealand/Australia Bicentennial Committee has developed a fine program of projects in both countries in 1988. I note that New Zealand has chosen to mark the Bicentenary by restoring and presenting to Australia the historic yacht Akarana, an inspired contribution to the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney which will, I am sure, be one of that Institution's most popular attractions.
The visit of Mr Lange to Australia in 1988 will be most welcome as a symbol of the closeness of Australia-New Zealand relations.

I am sure I speak for all honourable senators in reiterating here the thanks which the Prime Minister expressed to Mr Lange and through him to the people of New Zealand for the contribution New Zealand will make in 1988.

The point I wish to make, however, is that long after 1988 has passed, Australia and New Zealand will enjoy a deep closeness and affinity. It is not a relationship for one particular year but an abiding relationship. It is not a relationship of mutual interest in one particular sector of activity but a relationship of closeness across an extraordinarily wide range. The Prime Minister's visit to New Zealand fully reflected and confirmed this fact. There is a sense of deep satisfaction about what Australia and New Zealand are already doing together and a sense of great optimism about what we will yet do together in the future.
