In reading the annual report of the Health Insurance Commission, one gets the impression of a competently run organisation that has isolated the tasks before it and set about achieving its objectives in a systematic manner-and the staff of the Health Insurance Commission should be commended for their approach. We are informed that the secrecy provisions relating to the release of specific information to prescribed persons have been tightened up quite considerably in response to recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I think such a move is encouraging. However, the report does not reveal the problems of the Medicare system and its failure to provide a better quality health service for all Australians. In fact, in many situations the reverse is the case.

When Medicare was introduced we were told that it would establish a system of universal cover regardless of age, income or disability. There are many who would dispute the fact that this aim has been fulfilled. Australia's health care system is in chaos and crisis. Personal health care costs are up and our public hospitals are unacceptably overcrowded. Since Medicare began there has been a marked reduction in the number of beds available in public hospitals for patients who do not have hospital insurance and, as a consequence, delays of up to two years for elective surgery are not uncommon. This is so despite the fact that patients awaiting so-called elective surgery are often experiencing considerable pain and discomfort in the interim period.

An additional burden is to be placed on the public hospital system by the Government's short-sighted move to reduce subsidies to nursing homes. Instead of having the option of suitable geriatric care in a nursing home, many could face the prospect of spending their time in a ward of a public hospital with nowhere else to go. The elderly deserve to be treated with dignity and respect, not with the worry of who will care for them in their later years.

A case was recently brought to my attention of an 87-year-old lady, already blind in one eye, who was faced with a very lengthy wait for a cataract operation. This operation could provide the only means by which her failing sight could be restored sufficiently to give her some small measure of independence. Yet, as a pensioner of limited means, she has to face the prospect of not being able to have this operation. The costs involved in having the operation performed in a private hospital are simply prohibitive, particularly since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saw fit in the August Budget to reduce rebates for cataract removal. Is this a system that provides universal cover regardless of age, income or disability?

In another case of which I am aware a pensioner, receiving $224.40 a fortnight, is required to pay $56 of this sum for essential medicines, leaving her $168 a fortnight for rent, food, electricity, clothes and other necessities. The drugs that she must have as a result of her condition are not on the national health list or provided for under the safety net scheme. Again, I ask: Is this adequate medical care? The Medicare system itself has perpetuated the fee for service system that has encouraged entrepreneurialism in the health system and we have seen a proliferation of so-called super clinics-an aspect of the health system on which the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts has had cause to comment. Our health system is in disarray and needs urgent attention.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the States Grants (Nurses Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985. The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce new variable capital funding arrangements for hostels and to improve the legislative base for the management of the new nursing home recurrent funding system introduced on 1 July 1987. The Bill also introduces improved new arrangements for conditions of capital and recurrent subsidies for hostels. These measures will enable better targeting of Commonwealth funding to hostel accommodation and care for disadvantaged groups and will achieve greater efficiency in Commonwealth funding of nursing homes.

In April 1986, a review of nursing homes and hostels reported on a future strategy for the development of residential care programs for the aged. The Government endorsed the broad thrust of the review's recommendations and in the 1986-87 Budget commenced a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people. This reform program has the primary objective of responding to community needs by encouraging the further development of hostels and community care services, and of increasing the quality of care and life of aged people.

Implementation of the first two stages of the reform strategy is proceeding with the establishment of new needs-based planning arrangements, the development of co-ordinated assessment services for the elderly, the expansion of hostel and home and community care services, the development of a special services program, the phasing in of new recurrent funding arrangements for non-government nursing homes from 1 July 1987 and the introduction of quality of care standards for nursing homes.
The new variable capital funding arrangements for hostels, given effect to by this Bill, introduce the third stage of the program for reform of residential care services for the aged.

In adopting a staged reform strategy the Government has recognised the importance of effecting gradual change in the aged care industry to minimise disruption in the lives of the 110,000 frail aged people in various forms of residential care presently receiving Commonwealth funding. In developing the overall program the Government recognised that the co-operation of service providers and the community would be necessary to fully achieve its objectives and to this end the Government has undertaken an extensive round of consultations with service providers, consumer and welfare organisations, and State governments on the proposed funding arrangements for hostels.

Briefly, the proposed amendments under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 will enable the Commonwealth to target its capital funding for hostels to achieve equitable access to hostels of people with limited means and all other people requiring and choosing hostel accommodation and care. This will be achieved by variation in the level of Commonwealth capital subsidy based, among other things, on the proportion of financially disadvantaged residents to be accommodated and the capacity of future residents to contribute towards the construction of the hostel.

In 1954 the Commonwealth introduced a capital subsidy program to stimulate the provision of suitable accommodation for aged people. Administrative arrangements of successive governments have meant that capital subsidies are provided on a 2 for 1 basis up to a maximum subsidy limit per place. In practice, however, the maximum subsidy arrangements result in a subsidy closer to 1 for 1. A similar per place payment is provided for most projects, irrespective of the means of future residents or the financial capacity of the organisation receiving the subsidy.

Furthermore, current legislative provisions prevent refundable entry contributions paid by residents from being considered as part of an organisation's available funds in determining the amount of a Commonwealth capital subsidy, even though the practice of requesting entry contributions is widespread in the hostel sector. This creates two major problems. First, residents are uncertain of their rights attached to these payments, and many do not have any protection in relation to refunds of their entry contributions. Second, it increases the financial burden on organisations by necessitating that they find other sources of funds which can be considered as part of their matching funds for Commonwealth capital grants.

In addition, no formal link exists between capital and recurrent funding provisions and in the past this has led to the Commonwealth providing capital funds for many `motel-like' hostels which do not receive recurrent subsidies for care services as the residents are well able to look after themselves.

Consequently, the existing capital and recurrent funding arrangements do not target Commonwealth funds to organisations providing accommodation and care for disadvantaged groups or provide incentives for organisations to maximise the use of their own funds or of residents' entry contributions. As I have mentioned, this Bill includes a number of amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 designed to address these difficulties and to provide greater protection for residents.

The Bill enables the Minister to determine guidelines for the assessment of the amount of a capital grant to be paid for the establishment of a hostel. The guidelines will be gazetted, tabled and subject to possible disallowance. The guidelines will have regard to, among other things, any contribution to the capital cost of the hostel which could be made by residents and the organisation, borrowing of moneys by the organisation, class or classes of persons to be accommodated and the maximum amount of the grant.

Other amendments provided for in this Bill will remove restrictions on moneys to be taken into account in determining Commonwealth capital grants. The Bill will enable borrowed moneys which can be repaid by resident contributions or from payments made by the State or the Commonwealth (other than under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954), to be taken into account in determining Commonwealth capital grants.

The Bill also provides the Minister with the discretionary power to enable Commonwealth or State government organisations, or organisations which conduct public hospitals, to be treated as eligible organisations for the purposes of the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. This will enable some joint hostel ventures to proceed.

This Bill also introduces new conditions for capital and recurrent funding and changes the existing arrangements for determining conditions of recurrent funding. The new arrangements and additional conditions clarify `up front' the requirements of Commonwealth capital and recurrent funding. The Bill will enable the Minister to specify conditions of a capital grant for a hostel and organisations will be required to enter into an agreement in relation to these conditions.

The conditions of agreements for capital funding set out in the Bill must be met by an eligible organisation and include provision for compliance by that organisation with conditions of grant; the repayment of financial assistance and the recovery of amounts taken as representing the Commonwealth's interest. The conditions will also include that an organisation shall comply with the conditions of recurrent funding. This introduces a link between existing capital and recurrent funding provisions and ensures that Commonwealth capital funding is targeted to the provision of hostel accommodation for the frail aged. In addition, capital grants will be subject to the provision of accommodation and care of a determined number of financially disadvantaged people, to further target government funding to this group.

Similarly, this Bill enables hostel recurrent subsidies to be subject to gazetted conditions which will be tabled and subject to possible disallowance. As well as the current conditions enforced through the existing hostel recurrent subsidies agreement, additional conditions relating to residents' rights and obligations (including provision of refunds for entry contributions), accountability of organisations to residents and specified outcome standards to be achieved, will be included. Non-compliance with conditions may mean suspension or cancellation of Commonwealth recurrent subsidies.

I should stress that the details of those provisions which are to be gazetted, tabled and subject to disallowance will not be finalised until the Government has completed national consultations and discussions with service provider and consumer organisations.

The Bill also includes amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 which will simplify the administration of the capital subsidy program. These amendments change the formula for determining the capital cost of a home by enabling the cost of equipment to be taken into account in determining the capital cost of a home.

The amendments in this Bill to the National Health Act 1953 will facilitate the administration of the new nursing home recurrent funding arrangements introduced on 1 July 1987 and will introduce measures to assist fraud controls in relation to current administrative procedures.

The successful implementation of the new standard grant funding arrangements depends to some extent on the financial data obtained from nursing home proprietors. In accordance with the new nursing homes financial arrangements principles, at the end of each financial year a reconciliation between estimated nursing and personal care costs and actual costs is to be undertaken. Under current legislative provisions, it is not clear that details of nursing and personal care costs are required to be kept by proprietors. This Bill therefore provides that particulars in relation to nursing and personal care costs should be submitted by proprietors in a form approved by the Secretary at such times, and in respect of such periods, as are determined by the Secretary. These determinations will be gazetted, tabled and subject to possible disallowance. This amendment will allow prospective fees determinations to be calculated more quickly and efficiently.

Consistent with the Government's acceptance of the recommendations of the recent review of systems dealing with fraud, a number of measures in this Bill will assist in reducing the potential for fraudulent practices by nursing home proprietors.

The Bill extends the current provisions relating to inspections of nursing home records to enable an officer authorised by the minister to inspect documents or records that relate to the operation of a nursing home, wherever these records are kept.

The Bill also provides that the manner in which nursing home records are to be kept may be prescribed. This will overcome current problems where some proprietors keep their records on accounting documents which reflect more than one business operation making it difficult to verify during end of year reconciliations whether expenditure has in fact been incurred. The Bill also provides for extended evidence collecting powers and amends penalty provisions under parts V, VA and VC of the National Health Act 1953 to bring these provisions into line with penalty provisions in other Commonwealth legislation.

The Bill also amends the National Health Act 1953 to remove the Minister's discretion to depart from the new nursing homes financial arrangements principles in reviewing fees determinations decisions. These principles are an integral part of the new funding arrangements and were designed to minimise discretions. If the transition to a standard grant funding system for nursing homes is to succeed, the principles must be applied in all cases of review of fees determinations decisions. The Bill also clarifies ministerial review powers by enabling all fees determinations decisions to be subject to review.

As foreshadowed by the former Minister for Community Services, Chris Hurford, in his second reading speech on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 in the autumn sittings 1987, a new mechanism for approving the transfer of nursing home beds from one location to another is also provided for in this Bill.

In addition, another amendment to the National Health Act 1953 in this Bill gives effect to an undertaking given on behalf of the then Minister for Community Services during the Senate debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and prevents any action being taken against a nursing home under the new non-compliance with standards powers until a standards review panel has been established in the State or Territory in which the home is situated.

The Bill amends secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953 to bring them into line with similar provisions under the Health Insurance Act 1973. Currently, the information which may be released to prescribed persons or authorities is not specified. This Bill will permit only information of a kind prescribed by regulation to be made available to a person or authority. This enhances the protection of personal privacy under the National Health Act 1953.

The Bill also provides for a minor amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973 to remove, in the interests of protecting privacy of patients, the requirement for the tabling of instruments determining patients as needing acute care.

Finally, a minor amendment to the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 is also provided for in this Bill. The Commonwealth has provided funds to the States and the Northern Territory under the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act since 1985 to assist with the transfer of basic training courses for nurses from hospitals to colleges of advanced education. The number of places being partially funded by the Commonwealth is increasing year by year so that by the end of 1993 the hospital-based training courses will be completely phased out. By authorising funding for the next transmission, this Bill amends the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to allow the transfer of nurse education to continue at an orderly rate.
The new funding arrangements for hostels under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 are expected to result in savings of $7m in each of the years 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90.

The amendments to the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 will authorise, subject to appropriation, expenditure to assist in the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges of advanced education of $14m in the calendar year 1988, $21m in the calendar year 1989 and $28m in each of the years 1990 to 1993.
The other measures in the Bill have no readily quantifiable financial impact, although it is expected that they may result in some small savings in administrative costs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

This Bill implements in Australian law the treaty on fisheries between the governments of certain Pacific island states and the Government of the United States of America. The treaty will enter into force when it has been ratified by the United States and by 10 member states of the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency. To date, six nations have ratified the treaty, including Australia on 18 May 1987.

The treaty allows United States purse seine fishing boats to fish for tuna in the fishing zones of all of the Pacific island parties to the treaty under a single licence to be issued by an Administrator who acts on behalf of the Pacific island parties.
Access by US fishing boats to the Australian fishing zone will be limited at the outset to the area of the Coral Sea shown on the indicative map attached to the explanatory memorandum.

The treaty imposes rigorous enforcement responsibilities on the Government of the United States and has the effect of disapplying provisions in US law which have afforded US tuna fishermen substantial protections from the enforcement efforts of South Pacific countries in the past. Under the treaty, the US Government is required to pay $US60m in licence fees for fishing rights for the first five years, and Australia will share in a distribution of those fees between the Pacific island parties.

The overall approach the Bill takes to implementing the treaty in the Australian fishing zone is to validate a treaty licence as if it were an Australian licence under the Fisheries Act 1952. The Bill provides in clause 4 the circumstances in which a treaty licence shall be taken to be in force.

Clause 5 extends the powers of officers to matters in relation to treaty licences. While a boat licensed under the treaty is in the Australian fishing zone, this clause also validates the exercise of those powers by an officer appointed by another Pacific island party as an observer on board the boat.
Clauses 6, 7 and 8 exempt boats licensed under the treaty from the range of offences relating to fishing activities which are generally applicable to foreign boats.
Clause 9 creates the offence for boats licensed under the treaty of contravening the treaty licence conditions. These conditions are set out in Annex I to the Treaty.
Other provisions in the Bill deal with matters which are not directly related to the treaty.

Clause 15 creates a regulation-making power with respect to returning cancelled instruments issued under the Act, the regulations or a management plan. Management plans routinely require that the holder of a certificate of registration of units return the certificate promptly to the Department following cancellation of the registration in accordance with the plan. The new power will allow the making of regulations making it an offence to fail to return certificates in such circumstances.

Clause 16 empowers the making of orders by the Minister about any matter about which regulations may be made, except that orders may not impose penalties. Orders are required to be tabled in the Parliament and are subject to disallowance in the same manner as are regulations.
The Bill is essentially of a machinery nature for the principal purpose of giving effect to Australia's rights and obligations under an agreement of great significance in the Pacific Islands region.
The Bill itself will not affect Government expenditure and will have no staffing implications in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

Australia will share in the distribution of $US60m in licence fees, to be paid by the United States for fishing under the treaty for the first five years of its operation. After that, fee levels will be renegotiated.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SENATE ESTIMATES DEBATE

Senator MacGibbon asked, with reference to page 239 of the Estimates Explanations, why the Department is spending $33,000 on replacement of existing protective jackets with flame proof jackets? Has the work become more dangerous?
Answer
The $33,000 provides for routine replacement of other uniforms as well as replacement of the jackets for certain categories of staff.

With respect to the jackets, an accident experienced by staff in the State Electricity Commission of Victoria has led to reassessment of the suitability of existing issue jackets in the environment to which Electrical Maintenance High Voltage operators are exposed.
Thus the requirement arises not from a change in the `danger level' of the work, but from realisation of a potential, though remote, hazard.
SENATE ESTIMATES DEBATE-FLYING TRAINING FOR DEPARTMENTAL EXAMINERS

The Department employs Examiners of Airmen for tasks such as specifying flight crew operating procedures including rules and conditions of flight, simulator checks and check captain approvals. To effectively undertake such tasks Examiners are required to maintain a level of proficiency and currency on aircraft for which they are setting standards and requirements. They are required to hold a current licence and appropriate ratings and endorsements by virtue of their employment.
Examiners of Airmen do not check the technical competence of individual airline pilots. That role is performed by the Check Captain of the Airline which employs the pilots.

The Examiners are concerned with the setting of appropriate procedures to be followed in the aircraft and in the training provided by the Airlines. Having approved the aircraft and training procedures to be used in respect of each aircraft type introduced into Australia, Examiners monitor the performance of the Airlines in maintaining those standards. As such their role can be seen to be the protection of public safety by determining appropriate safety standards, monitoring their implementation and ensuring compliance. This role is clearly distinct from the day-to-day operations of Airlines and needs to be performed by persons independent from the airline industry.
The location of training is determined according to the most economical option. The extent of training done overseas is a reflection of relative rates offered, taking account also of travel costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to disturb the flow or the order of debate, but is it in order for me, Madam Chair, to refer to the Trade Development Council at this stage?
—We are considering the votes for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

—I just did not want to cut off a wonderful debate on foreign affairs. The matter I wish to raise relates to the rather odd role currently being played by the Trade Development Council. As I understand it from the annual report of the Department of Trade for 1985-86, the Council has as its function to advise the Minister on all aspects of the development of Australia's trade. I do not have the current list of members of the Trade Development Council, but I know that Dr Scott-a person of very high repute in the community and a very significant business figure-is still the Chairman. Mr Bob Ansett, a man who certainly has my respect, is a member. It seems to be a mixed group. It includes Mr Pak-Poy and a number of trade unionists, as well as Dr Fitz- Gerald.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Trade Development Council has assumed some rather different functions over recent years. This is typified best of all by looking at its contribution to the document Australia Reconstructed, which we find described on the cover as concerning an Australian Council of Trade Unions and Trade Development Council mission to Western Europe and a report by the mission members to the ACTU and to the Council. I can summarise what I wish to say by saying that it seems to me that this is much less a contribution towards what the Trade Development Council is meant to do, which is to advise on all aspects of the development of Australia's trade, and, rather, a last hurrah of those elements of the Australian Labor Party or the trade union movement which see the solution to Australia's problems as lying in a completely opposite direction to that being laid down by senior Ministers such as Senator Button, Mr Dawkins, Senator Walsh, Mr Kerin and various others who seem to me to advocate everything except the sorts of solutions put forward in Australia Reconstructed.

I do not wish to spend a lot of time talking about Australia Reconstructed because I think it is quite justifiably disappearing from public sight. It is a largely irrelevant document, written out of its time, and I do not think anybody, including the Government, will take any notice of it, and I welcome that fact. I acknowledge that the document has one value. It is that a group of trade unionists went to Europe, came back and talked about Australia in a way which acknowledged some of the realities which we face. They acknowledged the importance of international competitiveness and the need to lift investment, the need for better training, education and so on. The report pays lip service to some of the essential matters about which the Opposition has been talking for a long time. For example, I remind the Committee that in July 1986, in the document that we published entitled Policies for Business, we talked about the fundamental requirement that there be a lift in investment to meet the challenge of international competition and our current economic crisis, which might be summarised as a crisis of ever-increasing debt. What we hear from Government Ministers is the need for Australia to have an economy which is more flexible and which is able to meet the challenge.

If one looks at what was said by one of the most old-fashioned of the senior Ministers in the Government, Mr Willis, when he addressed the Employers Federation of New South Wales on the Friday before last, one finds a welcome acknowledgment of the need for greater flexibility in wages, the need to encourage such things as employee share ownership, another policy advocated by the Opposition for some time, and so on. Mr Willis, a most conservative Minister in my view, one who comes from the heart of the trade union movement itself and who in no sense has a reputation of trying to run away from his long-standing commitment to the trade union movement, advocates flexibility of a sort which is totally opposite to that advocated in this old-fashioned document. It suggests instead that we should have all sorts of committees established-if there is a decision to be made, for God's sake have a committee with lots of trade unionists on it!

The relevance of all of this to the appropriations is that this crude, simplistic, old-fashioned and useless advice is being produced at taxpayers' expense. I believe that the reputation of the Trade Development Council is not going to survive if it continues to be associated with this sort of exercise, and it is wrong of the Government to be using this instrument to produce what is essentially propaganda from the most backward parts of the trade union movement and from people whose views are simply totally out of line with the views of the Government itself. It is, in a quite gross and obvious way, providing a subsidy for one's trade union mates in circumstances which simply cannot be justified as advancing the national interest in the way that the Government itself sees the national interest as being advanced.

I think that it is disgraceful that we have this produced substantially at Government expense. The cost of sending this list of trade unionists around Europe was borne, we are advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, five-ninths by the Government and four-ninths by the ACTU. There was some misinformation given to Estimates Committee B, which was speedily corrected by a letter dated 8 October. A wrong answer was given by one of the public servants appearing before the Committee, but she wrote two days later to confirm that the costs of the mission were shared between the Trade Development Council and the ACTU in the proportion of five-ninths to four-ninths respectively.

That is one contribution that was made by the Government. When we turn to the actual production of this document, we find that, substantially, the document was written by public servants at, of course, public expense. The Department seemed to have an extraordinary amount of difficulty in identifying the cost to the public purse. I do not quite know whether it is understood in the Department that there is a distinction between work that is done for the public and the Department and work that is done for the ACTU, but it was unable to give us an initial answer with any clear definition. However, in a subsequent further answer, in response to a query in which I indicated my dissatisfaction with the reply which had been given, the Department attempted an estimate. It wrote on 19 November, in a letter over the signature of Mr F. C. Murray, First Assistant Secretary of the Corporate Management Division, with a breakdown indicating the time spent on Australia Reconstructed by a series of public servants. Those public servants are identified not by name but by level.

We find that the amount of time varied between 15 per cent of the office time to 100 per cent, which applies to some interchange officer whose salary was paid by the South Australian Institute of Technology. There are a range of amounts specified in that reply and it would appear that the wages bill for the preparation of this report is in the vicinity of $50,000. That report has been comprehensively panned by Ministers showing their complete lack of enthusiasm for it and by the various people who have chosen to read and comment on it. I say to the Minister that, at a time when widows' entitlements and the entitlements for unemployed youth are being reduced, and at a time when the English as a second language program has to be cut, I find it offensive that my money and the money of my Western Australian taxpayers is diverted to this sort of exercise instead.

In addition to this $50,000, the Department also met the total cost of publication of Australia Reconstructed-a cost of $74,686-although it expects $50,000 of this to be recouped through sales. However, another $25,000 can be added to the salary costs, even if that recoupment is successful. If the Minister can tell us, I would like to know how much of those sales were sales to government and how much were sales to schools. I gather that this document, which is not of particularly high repute, has been flogged to schools, and I would be interested to know whether this propaganda has gone to schools and whether some of the offsetting income is taxpayers' money being received under another guise.

The launch of Australia Reconstructed cost, I am advised, $15,000, and there were other expenses, including producing handouts and so on. It is clear that about $100,000 of taxpayers' money has been spent on the production, promotion and distribution of Australia Reconstructed. Quite frankly, I think that very few people-indeed, very few trade unionists-would see that as an appropriate use of taxpayers' money. I suspect that hundreds of thousands of people-all those families which have lost their family allowance and all those who have, in one way or another, been put under pressure by the Government and by its mishandling of the Australian economy-would say that there was a better use to which the $100,000 could have been put.

The central point I wish to make is that I do not believe that the production of this report is consistent with the long term respectability of the Trade Development Council and its being taken seriously in this important area. In the past, it has sent groups overseas for the promotion of trade. If we want to have an extension of the Trade Union Training Authority and educative exercises which convince some trade union leaders that international competitiveness is important, we should do that under an appropriation for the purpose. The Opposition will watch the future operation of the Trade Development Council with considerable interest.

The Council was probably originally appointed by a coalition government, and I in no way wish to suggest that the operation of such a council is not in the national interest if it is devoted to the objectives which were established. But I must say that I was quite horrified to find out that it was the base from which the Australia Reconstructed document was pushed forward. I think it is a pity that we do not have a procedure whereby some of these things can be recouped by Senate action. That might have been an appropriate thing to do.

I turn very briefly again to the document Australia Reconstructed. As I said, I do not wish to dignify what I think is a disappointing document by giving it very much attention but I draw the attention of the chamber to the sort of criticism which has been published by Mr Finucane, the Executive Co-ordinator of the Pilbara Iron Producers Association, who has pointed out just what is going wrong in Sweden, which is, of course, the model to which these people flock. I refer also to the excellent comments of Mr Russell Fynmore, the Executive General Manager, Business Development, for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, who made the point in his speech:
. . . the ACTU, while having the right to speak out on these issues-
I, of course, defend the ACTU's right to do that-
should do so in its own name, rather than under the subterfuge of being part of the joint Government, business, union initiative.

I think that there is an enormous role for the ACTU to play in educating the Australian community to the need for change, for flexibility, and the need to change our ways if we are to meet the intense competition which we face, whether it is from East Asia, South Asia, North America, South America or Europe. The competition is intense. It will not stop. It will get greater and greater. I simply say that to advocate the sort of directive approach to investment which this document advocates, to advocate the further bureaucratisation of Australian business, is a move in exactly the wrong direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) the very serious matter of the massive outlay that the Government would face if it were to proceed with the ill thought out plan to nominate for World Heritage listing the vast areas of north Queensland rainforests. If it has not, I suggest it should as there is no doubt that the Commonwealth will be up for a very significant cost to Federal outlays.

An expert evaluation by the reputable international accountancy firm, Touche Ross, indicates that the timber industry alone would been entitled to $60m compensation from the Federal Government-that is an underestimate-if it were forced to abandon its resources and its capital equipment. That is not a Mickey Mouse figure. It has been calculated by an internationally accepted organisation that has great experience in these matters. That $60m would be the minimum figure that would be owed. Indeed, the accountancy firm expects that the figure would be substantially higher.

However, let us not forget that that is only the tip of the iceberg. We also have to take into account the individual workers who are displaced; the private landowners and landholders whose property values will slump and who will be denied the right to develop their land as they wish; the shire councils whose income from rates will be reduced; the other industries in the area which will be adversely affected; and other businesses which rely on the north Queensland timber industry for the provision of services and raw materials. Senator Richardson ran for cover at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing, saying that he could not envisage most of these groups requiring compensation. Yet, he has paraded around north Queensland, along with Senator Reynolds and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), telling people that not one person will lose out because of World Heritage listing.

Senator Walsh's newfound financial obligations do not end with his obligation to pay compensation. Senator Richardson has made numerous offers of federally funded timber plantations to replace the industry that he is planning to kill off. He has spoken of creating 250 jobs in the establishment of new timber plantations. Independently, the timber industry consultants estimate that for every 250 people to be employed, a total of 6,000 new hectares would have to come under cultivation every year. They further estimate that the total cost of a program of this magnitude over six years, plus subsequent maintenance, would be around the $3m mark, including the cost of the land to be purchased as there is no crown land available. Even after this massive expenditure, the employment requirements would fall dramatically after the first six years as only general maintenance would be required.

I again ask the Minister for Finance whether he is prepared to commit massive Commonwealth funds of $200m to the one scheme that would be needed to satisfy Senator Richardson's commitments, or are Senator Richardson's commitments merely hollow rhetoric to dupe the people of north Queensland into accepting this flawed proposal? At the very minimum, he has committed the Commonwealth to well over a quarter of a billion dollars expenditure in a bid to muster local support for this environmental affair. This is the amount that can be quantified at an early stage. The final amount is likely to be significantly higher than that.

In the document Regional Development and Employment Strategy, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts and Senator Reynolds talk about creating 80 jobs in public works and 190 jobs in maintaining the rainforest after it has been included in the World Heritage List. Can the Minister for Finance give the Committee any information as to what this uncosted commitment might be to the Commonwealth? It is but one example of how the Government, if it is serious about making sure that people's lifestyles and jobs are not destroyed, will face enormous outlays in the next few years.

I also ask the Minister for Finance: What will happen to the 12,000 hectares of land that Senator Richardson is going to take over for forestry plantations? Maybe Senator Walsh can enlighten me as to whether this land, which will become government land, will attract local government rates and taxes or will be exempt? If it is exempt, will the Commonwealth Government fund the local governments for their loss of revenue? People are left wondering over so many things in this ill-conceived plan. I think Senator Walsh, who comes in here constantly asking the Government to cut its costs, should take a very definite interest in this plan. I believe that his Government is going to have to find somewhere between a quarter of a billion dollars and half a billion dollars to implement this ill-conceived World Heritage listing that will cost an industry $33m and wipe out 2,000 to 3,000 spin-off jobs. I again say that a lot of the people who will be affected by this decision will end up social welfare programs when their jobs are lost. Finally, I ask: Has Senator Walsh made any assessment of the whole cost of the World Heritage listing?

These Departments-
it goes on to list the departments-

By mid January 1987-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to direct my remarks to the taxation area of the Department of the Treasury. Before doing so I would like to comment that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) should be absolutely ashamed of the level of officers it sent to the Estimates Committee C because of their total inability to answer simple questions in regard to tax, which is something I think that exercises the minds, certainly of all working Australians, if not all Australians. I think it is worth quoting from part of the Estimates Committee C report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The representation . . . at the Committee's hearing, was particularly unsatisfactory in the latter regard.

That is in regard to the level of seniority of officers who attended. I interpose also to say that the Department of Finance and Department of the Treasury were represented by very senior officers, including Dr Higgins from the Department of Treasury. The level of attendance of Taxation Office officers was singularly disgraceful. The report continued:

The officers from the ATO who attended the hearing with some exceptions, were not able to provide answers to the questions-some of which were simple questions on taxation administration-put by the Committee and had to take such questions on notice.

The Committee strongly believes that it is incumbent on departments and authorities to ensure that officers who do attend Estimates Committee hearings are officers of sufficient seniority, experience and knowledge to assist the Committee.

Unlike all other Estimates committees which I attended, as at this morning Estimates Committee C had not received from the Taxation Office one reply to questions on notice. Later in the morning we received a list of replies to questions I had asked. I think it is worth noting also that it was only today that we received the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation. That makes our task and the task of this Parliament somewhat difficult.

Having made those remarks, I would like to comment on taxation itself. I refer to the report from the Commissioner of Taxation received today and to remarks made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech when he said that he had provided this country with the greatest reforms in Australia's history in respect of both equity and simplicity. I refer also to the indication he gave that there would be a taxation reduction for ordinary taxpayers. I think it is worth citing some figures contained in the report. The report states that in 1984-85 net revenue collected from income tax was $34.27 billion-or close enough to it. As at the end of 1986-87, net revenue collected from income tax was $45.962 billion, an increase of 30 per cent in two years. So much for the claim that people are getting taxation reductions.

It could be argued, quite correctly to some extent, that perhaps there has been a growth in the number of taxpayers. So there has. However, over that period the growth in the number of taxpayers-I guess returns as well-was 4 per cent. If we take the Forward Estimates and carry through to 1987-88, we see that the net revenue collected from income tax will have risen from $35.27 billion in 1984-85 to $50.185 billion as at the end of June next year. That is an increase of 42.3 per cent in three years. It does not matter which other area one wishes to look at; total revenue collected has gone up something like 30 per cent in two years. Sales tax has increased 20 per cent in two years. If one looks at the Forward Estimates for the year ended 1987-88 it will be seen that sales tax will have increased 43 per cent in three years. Therefore, we have the highest taxing government this country has ever seen. There is no sign that this will change. The comment that the Government is looking at reducing taxation is nothing more than a pea and thimble trick.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard increased sales tax by 66 per cent in two Budgets.

—If Senator Maguire had looked at the figures, he would not be interjecting. In view of the fact that the Treasurer made such a big note of the so-called simplicity and equity in his tax reform, I would like to ask: How equitable is this tax reform? It has recently been brought to my attention-in fact, I have a case history and I am prepared to get it for anyone who wishes to have it-that a taxpayer in Brisbane did not submit a return for one year. He was served with a summons by the Tax Office.
—For two years?

—For one year. He was served with a summons by the Tax Office. He went to an accountant where it was determined that he was due for a refund. The accountant contacted the Tax Office in Brisbane and explained the position. The officer-I can obtain the name of the officer if anybody wishes to get it-advised that under the circumstances the return should be submitted and the charge would be withdrawn. The return was submitted and, notwithstanding the advice given by the officer, the charge was proceeded with and the taxpayer fined some $350.
—His name would not be Keating?

—Talk about equity. The Minister will be aware of the celebrated case of the Treasurer in not submitting his own return for two years. Notwithstanding that as Treasurer his own behaviour should be beyond reproach he brushed off criticism by saying that he did not owe the Tax Office anything and was due for a refund after two years. From the point of view of equity I think the question must be asked, and could the Minister advise, whether there are two tax laws in Australia, one for the very ordinary Australian and one for the privileged.

SPEECH.PARA: Another question I would like to raise is in respect of the answers which, I inform the House, we have just received today. It is a capital gains tax question. I ask: Is it a fact that the renewal or extension by, say, a mineral operator of exploration or mining tenements under relevant States' mining Acts amount to a disposal and re-acquisition of a fresh asset subject to capital gains provisions? The response I received from the Department leaves me as confused as I was before. The response states:
Under the capital gains tax legislation, the expiry or surrender of an asset being a right-
incidentally, an exploration licence is not normally looked on as an asset, it is looked on as a liability; however, the Tax Office has different definitions-
or an interest to a right over property amounts to disposal. A subsequent renewal or extension of the right by way of a grant or otherwise is considered to be an acquisition of a new asset.
As far as I can gather, this is the reason given for it:
Generally new terms and conditions are attached to the re-grant of exploration tenements.
Okay, we know where we are going now. It is taxable. According to paragraph 1 of the response it is taxable if we get a renewed exploration permit. However, the third paragraph states:

Representations have been made concerning the application of capital gains tax to the mining industry and in particular the effect of a renewal or extension of a right. The Government has indicated it will consider the matters that have been raised by the industry in the context of a review currently being made of the roll-over provisions in capital gains tax legislation.

A determination has been made that it is taxable. The Government has been receiving applications from the industry and is currently reviewing them. I ask: what is the status of the review? The other question I raised was in regard to the evaluation methodology which the Department is prepared to accept in valuing exploration interests subject to farm-out. The response I have received states:

With regard to farm-out arrangements for cash, work program commitments, or a combination of both, the Commissioner has reissued a ruling-taxation ruling No. IT2378 of 24 December 1986-setting out the guidelines in respect of the operation of the legislation of farm-outs as well as the principles to assist in the determination of market value. A copy of the ruling is enclosed for information.

As I indicated, this piece of paper arrived on my desk at about mid-day today. The ruling is nine pages long. It is simply to determine whether capital gains tax should apply to a farm-out arrangement where there might be a work program, cash or a combination of both. It is nine pages long. So much for simplicity in the reform. I think I asked the question at some later date: Does the Department itself recognise how complex this is and that few accounting firms are starting to specialise in this area because of its complexity and the lack of understanding? I challenge honourable senators to look at this tax ruling which is nine pages long on the simple question of capital gains regarding farm-outs. When I asked a question on complexity-again, the answer has only arrived today; I am only reading it for the second time-the glib reply was:
It is expected that with introduction of any new tax a familiarisation period will be needed by the professions and the public generally.
It goes on. A question was asked:

`Are there any plans to simplify procedures, given the fact that records have to be kept for a lifetime to provide an ability to check and pursue them which must be an inconvenience and costly procedure for the Tax Office itself?

The answer was that taxpayers are expected to keep all the records. A few exceptions were made, such as the household refrigerator and other things that do not really matter. In regard to a question I asked in respect of pastoral leases in the Northern Territory converted to freehold, I am pleased to say that I received a satisfactory answer. I am not saying that I am satisfied because I agree with it, but it was one that I could understand and it made sense.

I asked one more question in respect of the Taxation Office returning 20,000 tax forms to taxpayers to have second declaration signatures put on them. I queried the cost. In fact, I was wrong. There were not 20,000 Tax returns returned, there were 92,000 returned. Postage cost $49,000. As claimed, only clerical procedures were involved and it was difficult to determine the precise cost of returning those forms. A question was asked:
Why was it necessary to return for additional signatures tax declarations which already had one signature upon them?
It was a fairly complex type of answer, but the response was that most people returned them with the second signature anyway. So I am not too sure what the whole thing achieved.

In conclusion, I repeat that we have a so-called tax reform system which is supposed to be equitable and simplistic. I ask: Is it equitable when we have the example which I gave of a taxpayer who had been singled out for not putting in his tax return for one year? He was told if his return went in all would be forgiven. He was subsequently charged and had to pay a fine. I have great difficulty reconciling that with a man who is in charge of the Tax Office being the Treasurer who did not put his tax return in for two years. I do not know whether he was charged or not. If so, I have not read about it. I am sure I would have remembered if I had read about it or the Press would have made sure that we did. The basic difference is that there is a law for the ordinary person and another law for the privileged.

For example, in 1980-81 the outlays that were financed from revenue sources linked specifically to outlays was $1.04 billion. This figure then rose progressively to $1.38 billion in 1983-84. In 1984-85, it was $2.1 billion. In 1985-86, it was $2.4 billion. In 1986-87 it was $3 billion and this year the estimate is $4.1 billion.

In other words, the amount of offset that has been occurring each year has increased quite dramatically-a four-fold increase in fact in the last seven or eight years. The effect of that, of course, in relation to the published figures for government expenditure is quite considerable and I think could well be claimed to lead to a distortion, and a distortion which has been increasingly important in recent years because it has had the effect of suggesting that the Government of the day-regardless of which political party is in government-has been curbing its expenditure growth by less than it has simply by resorting more and more to financing outlays through charges and fees. In the three years, for example, to 1986-87, expenditure other than that financed by fees and charges increased at an annual rate of 9.8 per cent, but expenditure financed through this offset process increased by 29 per cent annually. When I asked the Minister a question on that in the Senate a year or so ago, he said that, as he understood it, the Treasury and the Department of Finance had followed for many years the international accounting conventions which define what is treated as revenue, what is treated as outlays and what revenue can be treated as an offset to outlays.

Having heard nothing to the contrary from the Minister, I assume that that was an accurate statement. If that is the case, it still begs the question whether the presentation of the Budget Papers is as objective, as descriptive and as accurate as it should be. It seems to me to be a fairly important point if we are all trying to understand the meaning of the Budget papers that are presented each year. I would appreciate a comment from the Minister on whether the Treasury or the Department of Finance has been looking at that matter and whether there might be any suggested changes to the presentation of the accounts to take account of that fact.

The preparation of the Budget Papers in general is guided by the Statistician's definitions and the other international accounting conventions. SPEECH.PARA: One can make three broad distinctions, granted that at the margin the distinction is not always unambiguous. The guidelines which are followed are that where a charge is levied for a service provided-Senator Short used air navigation charges as being clearly one such example-that is counted as an offset to outlays. His argument, which I do not think has much to do with the Appropriation Bills, seems to be that it is conceptually wrong to do that because it gives the impression that, if charges are being increased, government expenditure is being reduced when it is not. That is the honourable senator's view; it is not a view that I accept, because where a service is being provided by government, if anything less than full cost is being charged to the user of that service, that margin is clearly a government outlay. However, if the full cost of the service is being charged, there is no net outlay. A charge of a regulatory nature may be applied, as distinct from a service provided. I cannot think of a specific example in the Commonwealth government sector, but a State government example is a driving licence charge or a dog licence charge. Charges such as that in the Commonwealth sector of a regulatory nature are counted as non-tax revenue. If there is a charge over and above a regulatory charge-a charge for a service provided-it is counted as taxation.

The main point Senator Short tried to make-if I understood it correctly-is that he was challenging the conceptual basis of the convention that, if a government is following a policy of moving towards or fully achieving, through charges, the cost of a service which is provided by the Government, that distorts the true picture. That is Senator Short's judgment: it is not one that I conceptually agree with. It is true that the Government is, quite deliberately in some areas, moving towards following that as a policy objective-for either complete or a higher proportion of cost recovery than has been the case in the immediate past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for his answer. I make it clear that I am not arguing against, for example, increasing use of the user pays principle, which is what we have been talking about in essence. The point I make is that, of the funds to meet government expenditure of, say, $20m to come out of general revenue, the expenditure figure in the Budget is $20m. If, on the other hand, it is financed out of fees and charges to the full extent of $20m, a nil expenditure is shown in the Budget. That is patently nonsense. As governments move more towards the adoption of user pays principles, there will be progressively a distortion in the sense of lack of comparability of expenditure figures from one year to the next. So what is shown in the Budget figures will not be an accurate reflection of the Government's expenditure per se. That is the point I am trying to make. As we move more towards the use of fees and charges, fees for services and the user pays principle, that in itself warrants a look at the point that I have made about whether the traditional and long-standing accounting conventions in this area are still valid.

Thank you for your letter of 9 October 1987 concerning the Wheat Tax Regulations (Amendment) (being Statutory Rules No. 182, 1987). You indicated that the Committee considered there may be a technical flaw in these regulations and request my advice.

The Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation (AWF) (which has ceased to exist under that name) adopted a resolution on 9 October 1986 to change its name to the Grains Council of Australia (GCA). The change of name did not alter the fact that the organisation continued to be the peak industry body representing wheatgrowers in Australia. This continues to be the case even though its functions have been expanded so that it is now the representative body for other grains as well.

Action was taken to reflect this name change in the relevant provision of the Wheat Tax Act 1957 by an amendment contained in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill which was introduced in the Autumn 1987 Sittings of Parliament. The calling of a July election precluded that Bill being passed by both Houses and it subsequently lapsed. The proposed amendment is now included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill which is presently before Parliament and which is anticipated to receive Royal Assent by mid-November.

There were strong practical reasons for proceeding with the amendment to the Wheat Tax Regulations prior to the passage of the above Bill. The wheat harvest proper commences around the beginning of October (although small amounts of Queensland wheat are delivered before this) and to maintain equity amongst growers it is appropriate that the same rate of wheat tax is applied to all wheat of season. Furthermore given that subsection 6 (2) of the Wheat Tax Act 1957 provides for payment of the tax in quarterly instalments from 1 October in any year it is administratively difficult and costly to vary the tax rate from a date that is not consistent with the above quarterly periods. Obviously delaying the increase until 1 January would have meant that the bulk of the current season's harvest would not have been subject to the increased tax and this would have impacted on the research efforts of each of the States for 1988/89. Wheat tax collections are identified by State in separate accounts within the Wheat Research Trust Fund and expended by the relevant State Wheat Research Committee.

My Department sought advice on this matter from Attorney-General's Department at the time the amended regulations were being drafted. The advice received was that there is a tenable argument that regulations to amend the Wheat Tax Regulations may recite the Grains Council of Australia as the organisation making the report on the basis that it is the successor organisation to the AWF with closely parallel powers and functions. So far as those Regulations are concerned, in fact, it could be seen as the same body in a new form. It was emphasised however that such a view of the matter is not beyond doubt and no guarantee of the validity of such regulations could be given. Attorney-General's further advised that if the matter was proceeded with, the basis on which the regulation was being made should be explained to the Governor-General. This in fact was done prior to his signing the Executive Council Minute.

Finally I would point out that the purpose of subsection 5 (2) of the Wheat Tax Act 1957 is to ensure that the industry itself determines whether it wishes to pay a higher tax to support research activities. There is no question that in the present circumstances this principle has been maintained.

Dear Minister,

At a special meeting on 17 November 1987 the Committee considered your letter of 3 November 1987 concerning queries raised by the Committee in its letter of 9 October 1987 about the validity of the Wheat Tax Regulations (Amendment) (S.R. 1987 No. 1982).

You may recall that subsection 5 (2) of the Wheat Tax Act 1957 provides that regulations prescribing a rate of tax ``shall not be made except after consideration by the Governor-General of a report made to the Minister by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation''. The enacting words of the regulations state that the Governor-General took into consideration a report ``by the organisation known as the Grains Council of Australia, formerly the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation''. In its letter of 9 October the Committee confessed that it knew of no rule of law that permitted a reference to the A.W.F. to be read as if it were a reference to another body, even one that continued to perform similar functions under a different name. Your letter of 3 November refers to legal advice obtained from the Attorney-General's Department that there was a ``tenable argument'' that the regulations could recite the Grains Council of Australia as the requisite reporting organisation on the basis that the G.C.A. was not only the successor organisation to the A.W.F., with closely parallel powers and functions, but also for relevant purposes the same body in a new form. The Committee has noted from your letter that on 9 October 1986 the A.W.F. adopted a resolution both to change its name to the G.C.A. and also to expand its functions to include a representative role for a range of grains other than wheat.

Given these facts the Committee has great difficulty in accepting an argument that the G.C.A. is the A.W.F. for the purposes of subsection 5 (2) of the Wheat Tax Act. The terms of that subsection, in particular the words ``shall not be made'' are extremely difficult to by-pass. The Committee therefore, remains of the view not only that the validity of the regulations is highly questionable to say the least, but also that a precedent should not be established of a tax being imposed by regulations whose validity was acknowledged by the Attorney-General's Department at the drafting stage to be so uncertain. The regulations might be seen by some to exemplify a worrying approach to the legality of administrative action. This approach might be seen to rely, not on the reasonable certainty of law made under Parliament's delegated authority, but rather on the absence of any litigant with the resources to challenge what is acknowledged to be eminently challengeable. The Committee has very serious reservations that this approach represents a departure from certainty and principle. The Committee acknowledges that there was a strong practical need for appropriate legislation to be made to deal with the imminent 1987 wheat harvest. Nevertheless, the Committee cannot see that this factor affects the question whether the regulations in question are legally valid.

The Committee takes the view, on principle, that the imposition of a tax, even one agreed to by industry representatives, should rest on a firmer legal foundation than that relied upon in this case. The Committee suggests that the proper course of action now may be for the Wheat Tax Act to be urgently amended either expressly to validate the regulations or expressly to authorise the collection of tax. The Committee considers that a significant principle of delegated legislative propriety is involved here which touches issues concerning the legality of administration. Disallowance would be a less effective remedy than some decisive, corrective action by you which both preserves the necessary status quo and guarantees the legality of the administrative actions in this case. The Committee urgently seeks your response to the suggestion that validating legislation should be passed immediately.
